abstracts.cdata!:
Project outcome is rated as
            satisfactory, while sustainability of the project is likely.
            Overall performances of both the World Bank and the Borrower
            are evaluated as satisfactory. A number of important lessons
            have emerged: Although the main focus of the project was on
            capacity building and project design was as simple as
            possible, expectations were overly optimistic. The
            disbursement was low, which is a typical problem for
            capacity building projects. This will need to be factored
            into future project preparation. The Staff Appraisal Report,
            while defining the objectives and the project structure,
            provides little detail on exactly what would be done and
            what results might be expected. While this complicates
            somewhat the process of ex-post evaluation, it has given the
            implementing agency tremendous flexibility in developing its
            work program. Such flexibility can be used to maximize the
            project's response to local needs, unexpected
            opportunities, and changing circumstances. However, this
            strategy also carries a significant risk should project
            staff not be able to meet the challenge. The autonomy of the
            national environmental agency, which is based on separate
            budget allocations and specific contractual arrangements for
            the staff (not the civil service) was particularly important
            for ensuring compliance with the requirements of the
            environmental impact assessment. This autonomy was important
            in safeguarding the project against untimely political interference.

abstracts.cdata!:
Over the period of four years the
            Environmental Management Project will support the
            development of a national environmental management capacity
            and help the Government implement the National Environmental
            Action Plan adopted June 1993. It will in particular pursue
            capacity building and institutional support, including
            streamlining and strengthening of national environmental
            responsibilities, reinforcing policy implementation and
            coordination mechanisms, promoting better preparation and
            enforcement of the environmental regulatory framework,
            developing an effective information system and monitoring
            and evaluation capacity. The project will also promote
            public awareness of environmental issues and the integration
            of environmental considerations in the education system. To
            achieve these objectives, the project will finance
            investments designed to: (a) improve the national
            environmental management capacity; and (b) improve the
            general level of awareness on environmental issues.
